items.title: Document XMLHttpRequestUpload

items.content_html:
FF110 implements the "focus fixup rule" on elements in https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1810077.

This was basically a spec clarification to state what happened to the focus and blur/focus events if focus was lost on an element because:

  • A style like hidden was applied to the element, which cannot accept focus.
  • The element was removed.

The spec changes says that the first case focus should be lost by the element and blur event should fire. This is what happened in FF110, which previously held the focus on the ineligible element.
For removal of element from document the focus should move to the body, but blur should not fire.

To fix this I have

  • explained the FF change in the release notes.
  • In the blur element docs I added a note explaining what the spec requires. I think that is a good place because you'll probably only wonder about this in the context of "why didn't I see the blur element in this case".

Other docs work can be tracked in #25496
items.title: FF110 Relnote and Element: blur focus fixup

items.content_html:
Description

Second sentence in the example text "It demonstrates how, for an animation that runs for an infinite time, you can cause it to remain in its final state rather than reverting to the original state (which is the default)" was changed to "It demonstrates how, for an animation that runs for specified time, you can cause it to remain in its final state rather than reverting to the original state (which is the default)" because example crearly shows that animation time is set for 3s and not for infinite time.

Motivation

Just wanted to help creators and users of the website.
items.title: Updated article example text

items.content_html:
Description

This PR adds font-palette and font-variant-emoji to the lists of allowable properties of ::first-letter and ::first-line.

Motivation

The spec says that all font properties can be specified on these two pseudo-elements, and the current lists on the MDN pages lack these two properties.

Additional details

This PR might not be correct due to the phrasing in the spec. See w3c/csswg-drafts#8635.

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Adding font properties to allowable properties of `::first-*`

items.content_html: this is a non-technical page because it really is hard to find how to install and mostly how to uninstall a PWA. Will link to it from the intro tutorial so developers can install the app multiple times (and uninstall) as they develop PWAs. This page is intentionally non-technical.
items.title: Install / Uninstall PWA: really basic guide

items.content_html:
Description

This is in scope of the PWA docs project: mdn/mdn#280

In this project, we are adding a number of new How-To pages that teach users how to implement common PWA scenarios.

This PR adds a new How-To page that demonstrates how PWAs can share data via the OS sharing dialog, as well as receive data from it.

Motivation

Sharing data, and receiving shared data, can make an app feel more naturally integrated into the OS it's installed on, and just more familiar to users. Showing that PWAs can do this just as well as native apps is something worth documenting on MDN.

This How-To relies on the Web Share API, which is already doc'd on MDN and well supported.

It also relies on the Web Share Target API, also doc'd on MDN, but only supported in Chromium.
items.title: PWA docs - New How-To page about sharing data between apps
